Overall, these data provide strong evidence that ASKtheta is a novel component of the BR signalling cascade, targeting the transcription factors BES1, BZR1 and BEH2.

Interestingly, plants with enhanced ASKtheta activity showed BR-related phenotypes resembling strong bri1 alleles. Phenotypic and molecular analyses are presented, indicating a regulatory role for ASKtheta in BR signalling.
Biochemical data demonstrate that ASKtheta activity is negatively regulated by BRI1, and that ASKtheta phosphorylates the transcription factors BES1, BZR1 and BEH2 in vitro and in plant cells.

To assess whether ASKtheta might function downstream of BRI1, the in vivo kinase activity of ASKtheta was analysed in wild-type and bri1-1 plants. For this purpose, an ASKtheta-specific peptide antibody (Figure S3) was generated and used for immunokinase assays. Consistent with the genetic concept, ASKtheta activity was downregulated by brassinolide (BR) (Figure 1e), showing that the protein kinase activity of ASKtheta is negatively regulated by BR levels and by the BRI1 receptor complex.

To further assess the impact of ASKtheta in the BR response pathway, we determined BR levels by GC-MS. Brassinolide, and its precursors castasterone and typhasterol, were dramatically elevated in lines overexpressing ASKtheta-Myc compared with wild-type plants. ASKtheta #10, ASKtheta #27 and bri1-1 contained 3.8, 0.5 and 1.2 ng of brassinolide per gram of fresh weight, respectively, whereas brassinolide was below the detection limit in Col-0 plants. The levels of these BRs positively correlated with the severity of the phenotype, abundance of the ASKtheta-Myc protein and its kinase activity (Figure 1a,b).

To identify substrates for ASKtheta action, a yeast two-hybrid screen using ASKtheta as bait was performed. Among the ASKtheta-interacting clones, the full-length cDNA of the transcription factor BEH2 was isolated twice. BEH2 belongs to the BES1/BZR1 family of transcription factors involved in BR signalling (Yin et al., 2005). CFP-tagged versions of BES1 and BZR1, which are known to be nuclear proteins (Yin et al., 2002; Zhao et al., 2002), served as controls. Constructs were transiently expressed in Nicotiana tabacum leaves by Agrobacterium infiltration. The fluorescence signals for the CFP-tagged transcription factors BES1, BZR1 and BEH2 were found in the nucleus. Although ASKtheta does not have an obvious nuclear localization signal, ASKtheta-YFP mainly localized to the nucleus, but low levels were also observed in the cytoplasm (Figure 4).

ASKtheta directly phosphorylates BEH2, BZR1 and BES1

To test whether ASKtheta is able to phosphorylate BZR1, BES1 and BEH2, in vitro kinase assays were performed with recombinant proteins. GST-ASKtheta phosphorylated GST-BZR1, GST-BES1 and GST-BEH2, but not GST alone (Figure 5). ASKthetaLOF, showed neither activity towards the transcription factors nor autophosphorylation, confirming that active ASKtheta is required for the phosphorylation of BZR1, BES1 and BEH2.

(a) Phosphorylation of BZR1, BES1 and BEH2 by ASKthetain vitro. Kinase assays were performed with purified GST-ASKtheta or GST-ASKthetaLOF, and GST-BZR1, GST-BES1 or GST-BEH2.
BEH2, BZR1 and BES1 are phosphorylated by ASKthetain vivo
These findings indicate that ASKtheta phosphorylates BES1/BZR1-like transcription factors in vitro and in vivo.

A. thaliana protoplast cells were transformed with expression constructs of CFP-tagged BEH2 and increasing quantities of ASKtheta-Myc. When ASKtheta was co-expressed with BEH2, phosphorylated BEH2 accumulated in parallel with increasing quantities of ASKtheta, whereas unphosphorylated BEH2 disappeared. Kinase-dead ASKthetaLOF had no effect on the ratio of phosphorylated and unphosphorylated BEH2, showing that ASKtheta activity is necessary for BEH2 phosphorylation.
In vivo phosphorylation activity of ASKtheta. (a) Phosphorylation of BEH2 by ASKtheta.

Bikinin, a small non-steroidal compound interfering with BR signalling by inhibiting the activity of ASK kinases, was recently identified in a chemical genetics screen (De Rybel et al., 2009). Co-expression of ASKtheta induced the accumulation of the phosphorylated form of BEH2, which could be blocked in a dose-dependent manner by bikinin, providing further evidence that BEH2 is a target for ASKtheta action.

annotation.text: In a dominant approach, we found that plants with elevated levels of ASKtheta displayed a bri1-like phenotype. Hormone sensitivity tests, quantification of endogenous BR levels, expression analysis of marker genes and protein kinase assays indicate that ASKtheta acts as a novel negative regulator in BR signalling.
ASKtheta-YFP was predominately localized to the nucleus, which is in agreement with previous in situ immunostaining studies (Tavares et al., 2002).
We identified the group-III GSK, ASKtheta, as a novel regulator of BR signalling.
Our data indicate a model in which ASKtheta acts in a BR-regulated manner downstream of BRI1 to phosphorylate BES1/BZR1-like transcription factors.
